welcomeMessage: Welcome, **@arcrin**, I'm your Copilot and I'm here to help you get things done faster. You can also [start an inline chat session](command:workbench.action.quickchat.launchInlineChat).

I'm powered by AI, so surprises and mistakes are possible. Make sure to verify any generated code or suggestions, and [share feedback](https://aka.ms/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release) so that we can learn and improve. Check out the [Copilot documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/github-copilot#_chat-view) to learn more.

metadata.sampleRequest: How do I build this project?

command.name: explain
command.description: Explain how the selected code works

parts.text:
Write an explanation for the active selection as paragraphs of text.

```css
  overflow: scroll;
```

response.value:
The active selection is a CSS property called `overflow` with a value of `scroll`. 

The `overflow` property in CSS is used to control what happens when content overflows an element's box. This can occur when the content inside an element exceeds the height or width of the element. 

There are several values that the `overflow` property can take, including `visible`, `hidden`, `scroll`, and `auto`. 

In this case, `scroll` is used. This means that scrollbars are always shown regardless of whether they're necessary or not. Even if all content fits within the boundaries of the element, the scrollbars will still be visible. This can be useful in some design scenarios where you want to maintain visual consistency, but it might not be the best choice if you want to avoid unnecessary scrollbars when they're not needed.

Remember, the `overflow` property only works on block elements that have a specified width or height. If the width or height are not specified, or if the element is not a block element, the `overflow` property will have no effect.

followups.message: What are the other possible values for the `overflow` property in CSS?
followups.title: What are the other possible values for the `overflow` property in CSS?
